Definition\r\n: Unique ID, other than a social security number (SSN), assigned by an agency, used to identify the traveler. SSN could also be used for this purpose but not a preferred choice due to sensitivity.
Data Group Name:
Travel Personnel Profile Information
(Official Travel Document Information; Ticket Information; Travel Authorization Information; Travel Itinerary Information; Travel Personnel Profile Information; Travel Reservation Information; Travel Voucher Information;  Traveler Payment Information)
Validations: (28) [Travel & Expense]: Traveler Profile Information Validation;
MITRE Recommendations:
Standard Data Values: Make TravelerID unique across all agencies.

FIT WG Recommendations: When assignment happens in the FM system, system functionality may be used to assign the number or a numbering scheme may be used. Numbering schemes may include some portion of the traveler’s name and Social. Some schemes use last name, although FIT notes that last names change more often than first names do, which could be a complicating factor.
Additional Sources: (20) RFP QMAD-JM-100001-N, Attachment 14 E-Gov Travel Service Standard Data Elements. August 23, 2010.

Definition\r\n: Unique number that Department of Homeland Security (DHS) assigns individuals who use the DHS Traveler Redress Inquiry Program (TRIP). This promotes resolution with previous watch list alerts. Under the Transport Security Administration’s Secure Flight Program, individuals with redress number will use it when making future travel reservations. (20)
Service Activity Reference\r\n: TRT.010.010 Travel Personnel Profile Set-up and Maintenance

Definition\r\n: This flag identifies if traveler is a mandatory or non-mandatory traveler. The government permits some workers to buy outside of their discount programs. These are called non-mandatory travelers. For example, members of Congress fall within this category. Workers who are required to purchase within the discount programs are called mandatory travelers. (20)

Definition\r\n: A three to eight (or more) alpha numeric code that enables airline and travel agents to retrieve the rules applicable to the associated booked or quoted fare.  The characters, including order, can grant some indication of applicable terms, but not necessarily all of them.  For instance, the first character is alpha and represents the associated booking class of service.  Subsequent characters may indicate travel restrictions and/or booking requirements that may include advanced booking, minimum stays, days of week, season limitations, traveler type, among many other qualifiers. (20, Augmented)
Data Group Name:
Fare Information
(Ticket Information; Travel Authorization Information; Travel Exception Information; Travel Expense Information; Travel Reservation Information; Travel Voucher Information)
Additional Sources: (20) RFP QMAD-JM-100001-N, Attachment 14 E-Gov Travel Service Standard Data Elements. August 23, 2010.

Definition\r\n:
Because the number of Fare Basis codes is virtually limitless, and because the extent of applicable terms cannot be ascertained without research, it is useful to categorize the fares booked or quoted, for reporting purposes, based on simplified categories, termed Fare Type.
Applicable Fare Types, to include:
• Contract Government - GSA Contract CPP fares, including, Dash CA and YCA, or Dash CB fares for official international travel.
• Non-Contract Government - Discount Government fares (DG or “me too” fares) offered by non-contract transportation providers
• Commercial Refundable, No Penalty
• Commercial Refundable, Penalty
• Commercial Non-refundable
Data Group Name:
Fare Information
(Ticket Information; Travel Authorization Information; Travel Exception Information; Travel Expense Information; Travel Reservation Information; Travel Voucher Information)

Definition\r\n: Indication of whether a transportation fare is logically the lowest price evaluated against other comparable fares (e.g., Lowest Logical Fare [LLF])
Data Group Name:
Fare Information
(Ticket Information; Travel Authorization Information; Travel Exception Information; Travel Expense Information; Travel Reservation Information; Travel Voucher Information)

Definition\r\n: A codified notation recorded in the PNR that documents a stipulated airline fare against which comparison can be made to the actual fare booked and purchased. The basis for determining the most appropriate comparison fare varies according to the travel management objectives of the customer, however comparison fares form the most basic metric for quantifying savings realized or lost in a given travel reservation. (20)
Data Group Name:
Fare Information
(Ticket Information; Travel Authorization Information; Travel Exception Information; Travel Expense Information; Travel Reservation Information; Travel Voucher Information)

Service Area Lead\r\n: Travel Authorization Data Elements: Need to add a data element that identifies trips protected from disclosure (300-70.103). Do we also need to add an "TravelAuthorizationGrossUp" data element? This data element would capture the gross up needed to eliminate the need for travelers to identify their non-reservation and per diem expenses. Does a separate data element need to be created for "Passenger" to identify when a traveler is authorized to be a passenger in a rental vehicle or GOV? If we have a GrossUp element, woudn't that eliminate the need to have mileage on the authorization, and instead only need it on the voucher, which is when the traveler will claim POV mileage actually driven?

Service Area Lead\r\n: Per Diem Data Elements (Rows 174-177): How did the working group arrive at the data elements for per diem? Why is Row 93 LodgingRateAmount not in with the per diem data elements? An adjusted per diem rate may be due to a NFS payment (next under) or could be a reduce rate or actual expense. Actual expense could be increased lodging, but M&IE allowance with no adjustment. A reduced rate must be authorized before travel begins (301-11.200). Actual expense may occur after travel has begun (301-11.302). The mileage rate data element (Row 179) does not stipulate airplane, motorcycle, automobile, or reduce rate, why do we need more than one per diem rate (PerDiemRate and PerDiemAdjustedRate)? What if the per diem data elements were lodging rate, meals rate, incidentals rate? Does number of days... include IDL per diem? How is it calculated?

Service Area Lead\r\n: Vouchers (Row 210): Need clarification on types of vouchers. There are really three different types of vouchers TDY, LocalTransportation, and Miscellaneous. TDY may have TDY Interim, TDY Final, and TDY Amended. An interim voucher could be submitted before the trip begins, i.e., Pre-Trip Vouchers. Example: an employee requests reimbursement of an advance room deposit it would technically be a pre-trip voucher, but it could be reimbursed on a regular TDY interim voucher. We also need to resolve the matter of whether non-travel related expenses, e.g., tuition, professional liability insurance, etc. will be part of the scope of our FIBF work. Currently, it is beyond our scope, but agencies use ETS to reimburse these types of expenses.

Service Area Lead\r\n: Constructive Travel (Row 220): Constructive travel is not limited to the cost of transportation. Constructive travel also includes baggage, tolls, parking, per diem, etc (301-10.306, 308.309, 310, 402).
